bestBHT.bht: Urbanus, a fellow laborer in Christ, is commended here. He is described as an urban man, symbolized by his name, and is known to be a helper. Stachys, whose name means an ear of corn, is mentioned as someone dear to the apostle. Urbanus is not only a fellow worker of Paul's but also of the Roman Christians, as indicated by the word our. The variety in these commendatory phrases may be due to specific reasons.

Marvin Vincent: Urbane. The correct reading is Urbanus, city - bred.
Stachys. Meaning an ear of corn.
Philip Schaff: Urbanus, our fellow worker in Christ."
'Our' refers not to Paul alone, since he says 'my' so frequently here, but to the Roman Christians also.
The variety in these commendatory phrases was probably due to specific reasons.
Archibald T. Robertson: Urbanus. A common Roman slave name found among members of the household.
Stachys. A Greek name, rare, but among members of the imperial household.
It means a head or ear of grain.
John Gill: and Stachys my beloved; this is a Greek name, he is said to be one of the seventy disciples, and bishop of Byzantium;"
he was, however, because of his faith in Christ, and love to him, or on such like spiritual accounts, very dear to the apostle.
John Wesley: Our fellowlabourer — Mine and Timothy's, verse21. Romans 16:21

In Romans 16:9, the apostle Paul makes mention of Urbanus, highlighting his role as a fellow laborer in Christ. Urbanus is described as an urban man, suggested by his name, and is recognized for his helpfulness. Additionally, Paul mentions Stachys, a beloved individual whose name symbolizes an ear of corn. It is clear that Urbanus is not only a co-worker of Paul’s, but also shared in the labor alongside the Roman Christians. The varying commendatory phrases used throughout this passage may have specific reasons behind them.

In this verse, Urbanus, a fellow laborer in Christ, is commended for his assistance. His name denotes an urban background, and he is described as a helper. Another individual, Stachys, is mentioned as being dear to the apostle. Urbanus is not only a co-worker of Paul's but also of the Roman Christians. The various commendatory phrases used here likely have specific reasons behind them.

Urbanus, characterized by his name as an urban man, is commended as a fellow laborer in Christ in this text. The apostle Paul recognizes his role as a helper and mentions another beloved individual, Stachys, whose name signifies an ear of corn. Urbanus is not only a co-worker of Paul's but also shared in the labor alongside the Roman Christians. These varying commendatory phrases may have specific reasons behind them.
